Hi-

> For those also interested in this, the previous link didn't work, it looks
> like it has an extra x at the end and should have been:
> http://pages.isir.upmc.fr/evorob_db/moin.wsgi

Oops, sorry for this. I don't know where the x is coming from.

>
> Perhaps it would be good to create such a site (either as wiki or a more
> structured set-up) for artificial evolution research in general (with
> tags/categories for sub-fields).

The main issue with a general website is that it will never be the main
reference. In my opinion, having a website with many sub-fields means that
most people in these sub-fields will not be aware of the website, that
they will use their own solutions and, overall, that the site will be
mostly empty. As a consequence, people will not think about this website
as _the_ place to check and to submit. Put differently, I think that such
a general website has a high probability of being a "ghost website"
without enough inhabitants to survive. It's "easy" to program a website,
it's much harder to make it alive and successful.

That's why we tried to do something for our own, small sub-field: our goal
is to be one of the reference pages (and even this is hard!).

The only way I can envision a successful general website is if it is
mandatory to publish a paper. For instance, GECCO could require the
submision on a specific website of the source code of every accepted
paper.

By the way, many journals in biology now require that the authors of
accepted papers put their data (and potentially their source code) on the
Dryad repository (http://datadryad.org/). I hope the evolutionary
computation field will be able to do the same!

[Dryad could be used by the EC community but it does not accept
GPL-licensed source code -- only creative commons --, whereas I think that
many EC frameworks are distributed with a GPL-like license]

Best regards,
-- JBM
http://people.isir.upmc.fr/mouret/
